commitMessage:"Apply IntelliJ-suggested code changes

`ToStringBuilder.java` was unnecessarily creating both a
`StringBuilder` and a `Stream` within `toString()`
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
where regular
string concatenation and `String.join()` would have been equally
performant and probably more readable.

`XmlReportWriter.java` was also creating a `StringBuilder` where
regular string concatenation would have worked just as well. Whether
it is more readable though is up for debate.

`TestExecutionListenerRegistry.java` was adding things to a collection
via manual looping
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: where calling `Collections.addAll` would have been\nshorter and probably more readable.\n"

commitMessage:"Make Gradle incremental build work

Executing `gradlew clean test; gradlew test; gradlew test` resulted in
all tests being executed thrice instead of just once. By generating the
shadowed `junit-platform-console-x.y.z.jar` only if code changes are
made

commitMessage:"Revert "Revise task inputs for Gradle plugin so incremental builds work"

This reverts commit b82dbe7dad48d520b9908f9d4ae4690bfb98bb1d.
"
commitMessage:"Revise task inputs for Gradle plugin so incremental builds work\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
executing `gradlew clean test; gradlew test;
gradlew test` resulted in all tests being executed thrice instead of
just once.

By dropping the `path` and `configuration` from the compile-time
dependency declaration
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
which
results in a single test execution instead of the aforementioned three.

Fixes: #631"

commitMessage:"Introduce ASCII-based tree printing TestExecutionListeners

This commit introduces `TreePrintingListener` and
`VerboseTreePrintingListener` which render ASCII-based tree layouts for
the executed test plan. If the default character set encoding (e.g.
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": \r\nfor the terminal or build environment) is UTF-8
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: then extended ASCII\r\ncharacters are used to display the test execution tree; otherwise
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
standard 7-bit ASCII characters are used to display the test tree.

A new enum named `Details` has been introduced in the
`org.junit.platform.console.options` package in order to allow the user
to choose between various display modes:

 - NONE: No test plan execution details are printed.
 - FLAT: Test plan execution details are rendered in a flat
column7:
line-per-line mode.
 - TREE: Test plan execution details are rendered as a simple tree.
 - VERBOSE: Combines tree and flat mode.

Consequently
column8:
the original `ColoredPrintingTestListener` has been
renamed to `FlatPrintingListener`.

In addition
column9:
the `--hide-details` command line option is now deprecated
in favor of `--details none`.

Issues: #369
column10:
#546

---
I hereby agree to the terms of the JUnit Contributor License Agreement.
"

commitMessage:"Use canonical names for exception types in assertions\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
if an unexpected exception was thrown from an
Executable passed to Assertions.assertThrows() the standard class names
of the expected and actual exception types were used when generating
failure messages. However
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: this could lead to ambiguity if the same\nexception type was loaded via different class loaders. Similarly
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
the
canonical name for static nested classes is more readable than the
standard name.

This commit attempts to use canonical names for exception types when
generating failure messages for assertThrows whenever possible. If the
canonical name of an exception type is not retrievable
column7:
the standard
class name will be used as a fall back.

Issue: #575

property in the TestEngine API as well as hardcoded support for Group
and Artifact IDs for discovered test engines within the
ServiceLoaderTestEngineRegistry.

This commit picks up where that commit left off by moving the logic for
Group and Artifact IDs to the TestEngine API in the form of interface
methods alongside the existing getVersion() default method.

commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
the Group IDs for the Jupiter and Vintage test engines are
now hard coded in lieu of updating the Gradle build and parsing the JAR
manifests directly.

on which classes are loaded via built JARs.

commitMessage:"Polish Javadoc for test\n"
commitMessage:"Invoke @[Before|After]Each methods w/ extensions registered for @Test\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
if an extension was registered explicitly for a
given @Test method that extension would be applied when invoking the
@Test method itself but not when invoking @BeforeEach and @AfterEach
methods for the corresponding test method. Specifically
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: only\nextensions registered at the test class level were applied in such\nscenarios. Consequently
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
a ParameterResolver registered to resolve
parameters for the @Test method would not be used to resolve parameters
in @BeforeEach and @AfterEach methods for that @Test method.

This commit fixes this problem by ensuring that the ExtensionRegistry
used to invoke @BeforeEach and @AfterEach methods is the registry that
is applicable to the corresponding @Test method.

Fixes: #523
"

commitMessage:"Honor the build dir in Gradle plugin (#538)\n\nBefore this change
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": there was an assumption that\r\nall users use the project directory as the buildDir.\r\nIn some cases
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
they are re-mapped to a single
buildDir at the root of the project to make management
easier. This change uses the builDir from the project
to set where the output will be.

Also to make the plugin nicer to use
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
users can set
the reportsDir to be a GString (or any object really)
and rely on the behavior of Project.file(..) to
resolve it to the correct path."

commitMessage:"Fix Javadoc references\n\: commitMessage:"Introduce @Testable to facilitate test discovery in IDEs\n\nSome clients of the JUnit Platform
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": notably IDEs such as IntelliJ IDEA
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: \noperate only on sources for test discovery. Thus
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
they cannot use the
full runtime discovery mechanism of the JUnit Platform since it relies
on compiled classes.

This commit introduces a new @Testable annotation that TestEngine
implementations can use to signal to IDEs and tooling vendors that the
annotated or meta-annotated element is "testable".

@Testable therefore serves as an alternative mechanism for IDEs to
discover tests by analyzing the source code only.

This commit also applies @Testable to the @Test and @TestFactory
annotations in JUnit Jupiter.

Issue: #537
"

commitMessage:"Deprecate expectThrows in favor of assertThrows returning the exception\n\nPrior to this commit
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: assertThrows() simply swallowed the exception. This lead to\nconfusion for users since it was not readily clear which variant should\nbe used. In addition
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
expectThrows() was the only method in the
Assertions class (other than the necessary fail() variants) that was not
named assert*().

expectThrows() method.

commitMessage:"Make DeGraph check faster and more user friendly (#532)

Until now the DeGraph check was run as a JUnit test in the root project.
This had several problems:

- We had to scan jars on the classpath to find violations in subprojects
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
schanning jars is expensive.
- There was no way to just check one sub-project for violations
- The fact that it was part of the unit tests made running unit tests
  unnecessarily slow

The test has been replaced with a Gradle task which is added to every
sub-project. You can now check for violations by just calling
`./gradlew degraph`"

commitMessage:"Ensure @AfterEach methods execute bottom-up w/in class hierarchy\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
a bug had been introduced that caused @AfterEach
methods within a test class hierarchy to be executed top-down instead
of bottom-up.

The cause of this bug was related to the introduction of synthesized
extensions for executing @AfterEach methods transparently as
extensions. Since extensions are registered in-order
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: the order of\n\"after\" extensions is always reversed before executing them
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
and this
mechanism reversed the bottom-up ordering of @AfterEach methods.

This commit fixes this bug by reversing the order of @AfterEach methods
before synthesizing them as extensions.

Fixes: #495
"

commitMessage:"Support checked exceptions in DynamicTest.stream\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": `DynamicTest.stream()` accepted a conventional\n`Consumer` for its _test executor_ which made it impossible to supply\na consumer that threw checked exceptions
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
which is in direct contrast to
the standard support for dynamic tests provided by the `Executable`
interface accepted by `DynamicTest.dynamicTest()`.

This commit fixes this problem by introducing a new `ThrowingConsumer`
that is capable of throwing any kind of exception
mergeBranchCommitId:null}: and\n`DynamicTest.stream()` now accepts accepts a `ThrowingConsumer` instead\nof a conventional `Consumer` for its _test executor_
column7:
thereby allowing
for custom streams of dynamic tests that may potentially throw checked
exceptions.

Fixes: #486

commitMessage:"Do not run DeGraph as part of standard test task\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
the slow DeGraph dependency tests were always
executed via the standard Gradle `test` task. The only way to execute
all tests without DeGraph was to execute `gradlew test -x :test` which
is not very intuitive for most developers.

This commit addresses this issue by introducing a new (empty) `degraph`
task in the root project which acts as an "alias" for the
`junitPlatformTest` task.

In addition
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: the dependency from the standard `test` task to the\n`junitPlatformTest` task has been removed for the root project
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
and a
dependency from the `check` task to the `degraph` task has been added
for the root project.

Consequently
column7: executing `gradlew test` will no longer run the DeGraph\ntests
column8:
but executing `gradlew degraph` or `gradlew check` will.

Issue: #481
"

commitMessage:"Reduce configuration time impact of versioning plugin (#482)

The call to `versioning.info.commit` in the `allprojects` block
lead to calling `git status` for every project. I replaced this
with a single call that is cached in a property.

This reduces the time to call `gradle help` from 1.6s to 0.7s.

We should consider only including this information on CI builds
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": \r\nas local builds are unlikely to care about an accurate build revision\r\nin the manifest."

it was also not possible to select a method by
its unique ID (UID) if the method accepted any array or primitive
parameters.

`findMethod(Class<?>
column7: \nwhere the final parameter is a comma-separated list of parameter type\nnames for the method to load. In addition
column8: \n`ReflectionUtils.loadMethod()` now uses a regular expression to\nrobustly parse the class name
column10:
and parameter type names
and then delegates to the new `findMethod()` variant.

Consequently the `MethodFinder` in the `JupiterTestEngine` now benefits
from this new functionality when resolving a `TestDescriptor` from its
UID. Similarly

based on _fully qualified method names_ and loading methods that accept

commitMessage:"Add forking support in surefire provider (#382)

Forking requires two methods to be implemented in JUnitPlatformProvider:
 1) `#getSuites()` - defines set of test classes for the future forks to execute
 2) `#invoke(Object)` - called inside a fork with a `Class` argument from (1)

This commit adds implementation of `#getSuites()` and alters
`#invoke(Object)` to support forking. It also adds unit tests for all classes in
junit-platform-surefire-provider module."

commitMessage:"Safeguard classpath scanning

Classpath scanning is now safeguarded against classes with malformed
names. The underlying error is swallowed and the offending file path
is logged. Other exceptions are swallowed as well unless it is a
blacklisted exception such as an OutOfMemoryError.
Such an error is rethrown.

commitMessage:"Ensure extensions cannot be registered as duplicates

Commit 6c146c5a76 introduced a regression that allowed an extension
implementation to be registered multiple times if registered in both
a parent and child extension context (e.g. at the class-level and
method-level).

This commit fixes this by reinstating logic for querying the parent
extension context as well when adding an extension to a child context.

This commit also improves the documentation on extension inheritance in
the User Guide.

Fixes: #390

- `releaseBranch` is passed to AsciiDoctor as `release-branch`

- `current-branch` in user guide is now constructed using `release-branch`

lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: simply supply a custom value to the Gradle\nbuild. For example

commitMessage:"Don't accept flag enable-exit-code. (#342)

This is a follow-up to e568a3563c417829a20eec988daa98797c8391b3. That
commit removed support for the flag `enable-exit-code`. It is already
deployed to the snapshot repository. Therefore we can now remove
support for this flag from `AvailableOptions`."

commitMessage:"Always use status code on exit. (#338)

I consider it helpful to always return a status code that is not 0 in
case of a failure. This makes it easy for scripts to decide whether all
tests succeeded. In addition I cannot imagine any use case that relies
on returning 0 in case of a failure.

The old implementation returned the number of failing tests as status
code if the flag `enable-exit-code` has been set. But this is only
possible for a small number (< 256) of failing tests. The problem was
that n*256 failing tests have been reported as 0 failing tests and
therefore could not be distinguished from a successful run by status
code.

The parser in `AvailableOptions` still accepts the `enable-exit-code`
flag because the project is build with an older version of the Gradle
plugin from https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots The
parser does not to have accept the flag anymore once a new version of
the Gradle plugin is pushed to the snapshot repository."

commitMessage:"Improve ExecuteTestsTaskTests (#334)

* Refactor ExecuteTestsTaskTests.

* Add specific tests for ExecuteTestsTask.

Parts of the `ExecuteTestsTask` have not been tested in detail. (There
are still such parts.)

commitMessage:"Redesign JUnit Gradle plugin with regard to the Platform

This commit makes the following changes which affect users of previous
versions of the plugin.

- The plugin is now called `org.junit.platform.gradle.plugin`.

- The `junit5` configuration block is now called `junitPlatform`.

- The `junit5Test` task is now called `junitPlatformTest`.

- The default test reports directory is now
  `build/test-results/junit-platform`.

commitMessage:"Reenable code coverage for platform modules in build

Changes introduced in 430e21d caused Clover-instrumented classes to
be shadowed by JARs pulled in via the new junitPlatform classpath
configuration. The net result was that tests were no longer executed
against instrumented code
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
leading to zero code coverage for the
respective platform modules.

This commit ensures that the user-defined test classpath precedes the
JUnit Platform modules when executing the ConsoleRunner via the JUnit
Gradle plugin.

lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: the JOpt Simple\ndependency had to be manually added. This technique is

commitMessage:"Ensure JUnit Gradle plugin does not influence project classpaths\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": the JUnit Gradle plugin modified the test runtime\nclasspath of the containing project by adding the junit-console module\n(and all of its transitive dependencies) to it. Consequently
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: the\n`junit4` and `junit5` engines were always on the classpath
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
both for
the project and for the task created by the plugin. The negative side
effect is that those engines were then included in the test plan by
default
column7:
even if the user didn't want either of those engines.

This commit addresses this issue by introducing a `junitPlatform`
configuration that serves as a classpath container for the JUnit
Platform modules required by the custom task created by the JUnit
Gradle plugin. This junitPlatform configuration has a dependency on the
junit-launcher (and its transitive dependencies such as the
junit-engine-api) and a dependency on the junit-console (but without
any of its transitive dependencies).

For example
column8:
executing `gradlew :junit-tests:dependencies` will result
in a dependency tree similar to the following.

junitPlatform
+--- org.junit:junit-launcher:5.+ -> 5.0.0-SNAPSHOT
|    \--- org.junit:junit-engine-api:5.0.0-SNAPSHOT
|         +--- org.junit:junit-commons:5.0.0-SNAPSHOT
|         \--- org.opentest4j:opentest4j:1.0.0-M1
\--- org.junit:junit-console:5.+ -> 5.0.0-SNAPSHOT

The classpath for the custom task created by the JUnit Gradle plugin is
then composed of the junitPlatform configuration and anything the user
adds to the test run-time classpath for the project.

Consequently:

1) No TestEngines are accidentally added to the test runtime classpath
   of the project.
2) No TestEngines are accidentally added to the classpath of the custom
   task created by the JUnit Gradle plugin.

Closes: #285
"

commitMessage:"Overhaul required/excluded engine filter support\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
the `EngineIdFilter` could only be used to
require a single `TestEngine` within the entire test plan.

This commit addresses this issue and revises our `TestEngine` filtering
support in the following ways.

- Renamed `EngineIdFilter` to `EngineFilter`
- `EngineFilter` now applies to `TestEngine` instead of `String`
- Converted `requireEngineId(String)` to `requireEngines(String...)`
- Introduced `excludeEngines(String...)`

Closes: #291

commitMessage:"Convert MethodParameterResolver to generic ParameterResolver API\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": the MethodParameterResolver API could only be\napplied to methods. In addition
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
the MethodInvocationContext API
needlessly stored the method which could be retrieved directly from the
supplied Parameter.

This commit addresses these issues by converting the
MethodParameterResolver into a generic ParameterResolver API that can
be used to resolve parameters for both methods and constructors. At the
moment
column7:
there is no first-class support for resolving
constructor parameters in the JUnit 5 TestEngine.

Specifically
column8:
this commit includes the following changes.

 - Renamed MethodParameterResolver to ParameterResolver
 - Replaced MethodInvocationContext arguments in ParameterResolver with
   Optional<Object> for the target of method invocations
 - Moved MethodInvocationContext to the junit5-engine module for
   internal use

In addition
column9:
this commit introduces a proof of concept implementation
for constructor injection in the form of a ConstructorInvoker which is
tested in ParameterResolverTests.constructorInjectionProofOfConcept().

Closes: #267

commitMessage:"Require floating point deltas to be positive

This commit adds a check that the delta argument supplied to
`assertEquals(float
column7:
double)` is positive. Same check is applied to methods that accept a
message or message supplier.

This check is needed because it does not make sense to compare two
floating point numbers within negative or zero delta.

Issue: #269
"

commitMessage:"Fix Javadoc references\n\: commitMessage:"Add assertEquals() for doubles & floats with delta\n\nThis commit introduces `assertEquals(double
column7:
float)` where the third parameter is a
delta. The first two parameters are compared within this given delta.
Also added methods with delta parameter that accept a message and a
message supplier.

Such methods are needed because exact comparison of floating point
numbers does not always make sense.

commitMessage:"Ensure JAR manifests are only generated when necessary\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
JAR manifests were generated with dynamic values
for the buildDate and buildTime for every Gradle run. This resulted in
project JARs being rebuilt even if nothing was changed in the projects.
Since project JARs serve as inputs into the testing tasks of other
projects
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
the net effect was that tests would always be executed even
if nothing had actually changed.

This commit addresses this issue by modifying the Gradle build so that
JAR manifests are only generated/regenerated if the code for the
corresponding project is compiled/recompiled.

Fixes: #266
"

commitMessage:"Polishing\n"
commitMessage:"Introduce deactivation mechanism for conditions\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": there was no way to deactivate or turn off\nsupport for conditional test execution. In other words
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
there was no
way to execute a @Disabled test and no way to deactivate custom
implementations of ContainerExecutionCondition or
TestExecutionCondition.

This commit addresses this issue by introducing support for supplying a
`junit.conditions.deactivate` pattern to the Launcher via a
configuration parameter in the TestDiscoveryRequest.

If the `junit.conditions.deactivate` pattern consists solely of an
asterisk (*)
mergeBranchCommitId:null}: all conditions will be deactivated. Otherwise
column7:
the
pattern will be used to match against the fully qualified class name
(FQCN) of each registered condition. Any dot (.) in the pattern will
match against a dot (.) or a dollar sign ($) in the FQCN. Any asterisk
(*) will match against one or more characters in the FQCN. All other
characters in the pattern will be matched one-to-one against the FQCN.

Examples:

- *: deactivates all conditions.
- org.junit.*: deactivates every condition under the org.junit base
  package and any of its subpackages.
- *.MyCondition: deactivates every condition whose simple class name is
  exactly MyCondition.
- *System*: deactivates every condition whose simple class name
  contains System.
- org.example.MyCondition: deactivates the condition whose FQCN is
  exactly org.example.MyCondition.

Issue: #78

commitMessage:"Simplify interface of the visitor.

Every visitor gets the instance of the TestDescriptor and a Runnable for
deleting it from the hierarchy. Everybody who has access to a
TestDescriptor can therefore delete it. That's why I added the delete
method to the TestDescriptor interface because I think that this is
easier to understand compared to the Runnable.

commitMessage:"Ensure extensions are registered top-down w/in class hierarchy

This commit reworks the findRepeatableAnnotations() search algorithm in
AnnotationUtils so that inherited
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
repeatable annotations are correctly
discovered within a class hierarchy using top-down ordering.

Furthermore
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
this commit slightly tweaks the performance of the
algorithm by avoiding unnecessary collection creation and duplicated
checks within recursive calls.

Issue: #208
"

commitMessage:"Fix Javadoc references\n\: commitMessage:"Rename BeforeEachAndAfterEachComposedAnnotationTests for consistency\n"
commitMessage:"Ensure that repeatable annotations are discovered in superclasses\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": it was impossible to declare `@ExtendWith` on a\nsuperclass and have it discovered. On the contrary
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
the declaration
would simply be silently ignored.

The same holds true for any other repeatable annotation that is looked
up via JUnit 5's AnnotationUtils.

This commit fixes this problem by completely overhauling the
findRepeatableAnnotations() search algorithm in AnnotationUtils.

commitMessage:"Upgrade to Spotless 1.3.3 with Eclipse 4.5.2 support

The upgrade to Spotless 1.3.3 brings with it all of the bug fixes
applied to the Eclipse formatter since Eclipse 4.5 M6.

For example
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
whitespace is now properly inserted after array type
declarations in annotation attributes as well as before "implements"
in class declarations.

Anyone developing JUnit 5 in Eclipse should therefore upgrade to
Eclipse 4.5.2+ or 4.6+.

commitMessage:"Validate resolved parameter types in MethodInvoker\n\nIn certain scenarios
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
a registered MethodParameterResolver may claim to
support a particular Parameter only later to discover the type of value
it resolves is not assignment compatible with the type requested by the
method.

Prior to this commit
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: the MethodInvoker did not validate the type of\nvalue returned by a MethodParameterResolver. Consequently
column7: ReflectionUtils.invokeMethod() would throw an\nIllegalArgumentException with the message \"argument type mismatch\".\nFrom this information
column9:
it is not possible to discern which
resolver was the culprit or which parameter could not be resolved
properly.

This commit addresses this issue by validating the type of object
resolved by a MethodParameterResolver. If the resolved type is
incompatible
column10: an appropriate ParameterResolutionException is thrown.\n\nIn addition
column11:
MethodInvoker now logs successful parameter resolution in
order to ease debugging.

commitMessage:"Support registration of extensions that implement multiple APIs

Prior to this commit it was (seemingly) not possible to
programmatically register an extension that implemented multiple
ExtensionPoint APIs via the ExtensionPointRegistry with a single
'register(...)' invocation. It was in fact possible
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
but the user had
to declare that the extension only implemented one of the many APIs
which could lead the user to believe that the extension would not be
registered for all implemented APIs.

This commit remedies this situation by introducing additional
register() methods in ExtensionPointRegistry which make it clear that
an extension can be registered for multiple APIs simultaneously.

Furthermore
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
the example TimingExtension has been updated to make use of
this new feature.

Issue: #122
"

commitMessage:"Fix Javadoc references\n\: commitMessage:"Introduce source in RegisteredExtensionPoint\n\nIn order to improve error reporting and logging
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
a new 'source'
property has been introduced in RegisteredExtensionPoint.

If an extension point is registered declaratively via @ExtendWith
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595: the\n'extensionPoint' and 'source' properties will contain a reference to\nthe same object; however
mergeBranchCommitId:null}: if an extension point is registered\nprogrammatically -- for example
column7:
by an ExtensionRegistrar as a lambda
expression or by the framework via the TestExtensionRegistry -- the
'source' may be the ExtensionRegistrar that registered the extension
point
column8: the underlying method that implements the extension point API
column9:
or similar.

The source is currently used for error reporting in
ExtensionPointSorter when conflicting extensions are encountered. In
addition
column10:
the source is logged under the
'org.junit.gen5.engine.junit5.execution' category at the TRACE log
level whenever an extension is registered.

Issue: #112
"

commitMessage:"Make LogManager configurable in JUnit5Plugin

This commit introduces a new optional `logManager` property in
JUnit5Extension that is used by the JUnit5Plugin to set the LogManager
for Java Util Logging when executing tests via the `junit5Test` task.

This new feature can be configured as follows:

```
junit5 {
	matchClassName '.*Tests'
	logManager 'org.apache.logging.log4j.jul.LogManager'
}
```

Issue: #113

commitMessage:"Fix Javadoc references\n\: commitMessage:"Do not wrap checked exceptions in Assertions.assertAll()\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10": assertAll() wrapped a checked exception in a\nRuntimeException and threw the RuntimeException. This behavior
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
is undesirable since it hides the actual cause of the failure.

This commit addresses this issue by 'masking' checked exceptions as
unchecked exceptions without actually wrapping them.

commitMessage:"Mask checked exceptions as unchecked exceptions in ReflectionUtils\n\nPrior to this commit
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
ReflectionUtils.handleException() wrapped checked
exceptions in a TargetExceptionWrapper (a subclass of RuntimeException).
This forced clients of ReflectionUtils to manually handle unwrapping of
checked exceptions.

This commit introduces a new throwAsRuntimeException() method in
ReflectionUtils which uses a reflective hack (based on generics and type
erasure) that tricks the Java compiler into believing that the thrown
exception is an unchecked exception. This approach allows both checked
and unchecked exceptions to transparently propagate up the call stack
without forcing callers to explicitly handle checked exceptions. In
addition
lastCommitId:"fd6b40ba08aff580bd450ab595:
this approach avoids the need to wrap/unwrap checked
exceptions via the TargetExceptionWrapper.

Furthermore
mergeBranchCommitId:null}: this commit refactors exception handling code within the\nJUnit 5 engine to use the newly introduced ThrowableCollector API for\nconsistent
column7:
simplified tracking of exceptions.

Issue: #64

This commit moves the MethodArgumentResolver API and related classes to
the junit5-api for public consumption.

Furthermore
commitDate:"2025-07-03 01:07:10":
this commit introduces the first public extension point for
third-parties: a custom MethodArgumentResolver can now be registered via
the new @TestDecorators annotation at the test class level.

Note
mergeBranchCommitId:null}:
that the current implementation for building up the
DefaultMethodArgumentResolverRegistry is still a work in progress. See
TODOs in the code for details on open issues.
